titleStmt.title: Dr. Martin Luthers prophecies of the destruction of Rome and the downfall of the Romish religion. And how the Papists for treachery and hypocrisie shall at last become hated, and contemned [sic] by all nations. Here are likewise some of the eminent prophecies of that most learned mathematician and prophet Michael Nostredamus, concerning England and France, and those strange occurrences which are likely to happen to both those countreys in these later dayes, with an account of some of the prophecies of Michael Nostredamus which have been fulfilled here in England already. Luther's motto writ by himself. Licensed, May 7. 1679.

titleStmt.title: Dr. Martin Luthers prophecies of the destruction of Rome and the downfall of the Romish religion. And how the Papists for treachery and hypocrisie shall at last become hated, and contemned [sic] by all nations. Here are likewise some of the eminent prophecies of that most learned mathematician and prophet Michael Nostredamus, concerning England and France, and those strange occurrences which are likely to happen to both those countreys in these later dayes, with an account of some of the prophecies of Michael Nostredamus which have been fulfilled here in England already. Luther's motto writ by himself. Licensed, May 7. 1679.

Nostradamus, 1503-1566.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Dr. Martin Luthers PROPHECIES OF THE DESTRUCTION OF ROME, AND THE DOWNFALL OF THE Romi≈øh Religion.
And how the Papi≈øts for Treachery and Hypocri≈øie ≈øhall at la≈øt become hated, and contemned by all Nations.

Here are likewi≈øe ≈øome of the eminent Prophecies of that mo≈øt Learned Mathematician and Prophet Michael No≈øtredamus, concerning England and France, and tho≈øe ≈øtrange occurrences which are likely to happen to both tho≈øe Countreys in the≈øe later dayes, with an Account of ≈øome of the Prophecies of Michael No≈øtredamus which have been fulfilled here in England already.
Lather's Motto Writ by him≈øelf, Pe≈øtis eram vivens, moriens ero Mors tua Papa.
Licen≈øed, May 7. 1 ‚Ä¢ 79.
LONDON, Printed for W.W.

div.head: Dr. Martin Luther's Prophecies of the De≈øtruction of Rome, and the Downfall of the Romi≈øh Religion.
div.p: TO wa≈øte much time in the needle≈øs Commendation of that Learned, and Pious Reformer, Dr. Martin Luther, would be as great an Impertinence as that of the young Rhetorician's, who ≈øpent three hours in an elaborate Declamation on the refulgency of the glorious Sun-beams. They are both ≈øo apparent to any Rational or Inqui≈øitive Creature, that it would be but a Tautologie to applaud them; we daily enjoy the ine≈øtimable benefit of either: for as the one delivered us from that uncomfortable darkne≈øs which fir≈øt brooded on the primitive Chaos, and hatcht nothing but Confu≈øion; ≈øo the other like a Friendly Pillar of Divine Light, kindly conducted us out of tho≈øe dangerous paths of Super≈øtition, and Idolatry, which would have led us into everla≈øting De≈øtruction.

But if after all tho≈øe mighty obligations he has done all the Reformed Churches in Europe, there ≈øhould any one yet remain bruiti≈øhly ignorant of his Virtues and Indowments, I ≈øhall in a word acquaint them who this Luther was.

1. It was he who (if I may ≈øpeak it with reverence) like our Saviour had the honour to be prophe≈øied of before he was born; and this even the Romans them≈øelves cannot deny, ≈øince their own Hi≈øtories acquaint us that one John Hilton a per≈øon they them≈øelves held in great veneration for piety and gift of Prophecie, wrote thus almo≈øt a hundred years before Luther had declared him≈øelf again≈øt the Church of Rome. Much about the year 1516. the My≈øterie of Vngodline≈øs ≈øhall begin to be di≈øcovered, and the Son of Righteou≈øne≈øs ≈øhine forth in the Truth of the Go≈øpel, and Popery ≈øhall in Germany, and other parts of the World then receive a Sudden Declen≈øion. This
Prophecie was certainly fulfilled by Laither who appeared at that time again≈øt Rome, and in ≈øpite of all her then domineering Tyranny gave her a greater blow than ever ≈øhe received either before or ≈øince.

2. It was he of whom the Martyr John Hus on that day he ≈øuffered at Con≈øtance ≈øaid; You now roa≈øt a Goo≈øe (for ≈øo Hus ≈øignifies) but one hundred years hence you ≈øhall hear a Swan ≈øing, whom you ≈øhall not be able neither to roa≈øt, nor overcome.

3. It was he who was graced with the Honourable title of Ma≈øter of Arts at twenty years of Age. 'Twas he who while≈øt he was peru≈øing certain Books in the Library of the Colledge of Orphord happened to meet with a Copy of the Latin Bible, which he never had ≈øeen before, and having to his great admiration ob≈øerved there were more Evangelical and Apo≈øtolical Texts in it than were ≈øuffered to be read openly in Churches, he thereupon ≈øet him≈øelf to the Tran≈ølating of the five Books of Mo≈øes, and afterwards fini≈øhed both them and the remainder of the Old and the New Te≈øtament, which was by ≈øome Popi≈øh Bi≈øhops and Prie≈øts forbid to be read to the People. In fine, it was Dr. M. Luther whom God in his infinite wi≈ødom rai≈øed, and furni≈øhed with a ≈øufficient portion of Care, Courage and Learning to In≈øpect and Detect the damnable Super≈øtition and Idolatry of the Church of Rome, which he re≈øolutely performed, notwith≈øtanding all the Threats and Dangers he knew he was to go through if he per≈øi≈øted in ≈øo doing. And la≈øtly it was he to whom Germany, Denmark, Bohemia and mo≈øt of the Prote≈øtant Churches in the world are in a great mea≈øure beholding for their glorious Reformation.

Thus much I thought fit to premi≈øe, that the mo≈øt ≈øcrupulous Reader may le≈øs wonder that the Almighty ≈øhould entru≈øt this worthy Champion of the now Reformed Religion with the Spirit of Prophecie which he was plea≈øed to exerci≈øe on him≈øelf, ≈øaying ≈øome weeks before he Dyed, When I return to Wittemberg, I will be lodged in a Coffin, and will render to the worms a fat Luther to feed on; and ≈øo it ≈øell out, for within two dayes after he came thither he dyed, but a little before his Expiration call'd for Pen and Ink, and wrote this following Ver≈øe,
Pe≈øtis eram vivens, moriens ero mors tua Papa. Which Melancthon, one of his dear Friends, taking as a prophetick rapture, turned into a Di≈øtick of the ≈øame meaning: Thus,
Qui fuit dum vixit tua pe≈øtis (Papa) Lutherus,
Hic tibi cau≈øa, ≈øuo funere, mortis erit. Both of which may be thus paraphra≈øtically turned into Engli≈øh:
As Luther Living was Romes plague, ≈øo ≈øhall
Her Fall be caus'd by his mourn'd Funeral.

But long before this Luther was ob≈øerv'd by all the Students at Wittemberg to be endowed with the Spirit of Prophecie which he frequently committed to po≈øterity, the greate≈øt part of which were in pre≈øaging the Di≈ø≈øolution of tho≈øe two grand temporal enemies of truth and Religion, the Turk and the Pope.

Concerning the later of which, in Luther Colloq. p. 328. he thus prophe≈øieth, The Pope mu≈øt fall and Popery with him, ≈øince it is downright Bla≈øphemy to hold as he does, viz. that the final cau≈øe of the In≈øtitution of Humane Traditions, is the true Service and wor≈øhip of God: and that it is nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation; contrary to that of St. Paul, If either we or an Angel from Heaven preach any other Doctrine to you than what we have preached, let him be accur≈øed.

In another Prophecie Luther thus Inferreth the Popes Downfall. Idem pag. 312. Antichri≈øt, ≈øayes he, mu≈øt fall, and it plainly appears that the Pope is the true Antichri≈øt, becau≈øe tho≈øe that tran≈øgre≈øs his Decrees or violate his Statutes are far more vigorou≈øly and ≈øeverely puni≈øhed than tho≈øe who offend the Laws of God, which is a palpable exalting of him≈øelf above the Almighty, and therefore he is mo≈øt properly called Antichri≈øt, &c.

Again ≈øays Luther, the Pope mu≈øt and ≈øhall fall by rea≈øon the blindne≈øs of the Popelins is ≈øo great and horrible that they hold the Reconciliation of the Living (which though they pretend is a Sacrifice) yet all their Canoni≈øts, School-Divines and Pulpit preachers utterly di≈øapprove it.

And in another place he predicts the Papal overthrow thus, The Pope ≈øayes he, mu≈øt fall, for that like a right Jew he boa≈øteth to enjoy by Chri≈øt a Temporal Kingdom, he alone
will have all the Power, and Authority, he will rule and Determine all Councils, and incroach upon them under the Name of Chri≈øt. If one ≈øhould have de≈ølowred the Virgin Mary, or Crucified Chri≈øt, yet the Pope for money would undertake to pardon and forgive the ≈øame. Therefore his Dominion is but ≈øhort and will be brought to ruine according to the time ≈øignified by the number of the Bea≈øt, in the thirteenth of the Revelations. Page 306.

Again ≈øaith he, Popedom mu≈øt fall, for that it hath been alwayes managed by wicked per≈øons and corre≈øpondent to the impiety of their Doctrine: for as the Creator is in this ca≈øe, ≈øuch mu≈øt be the Creature. Pope Alexander was a Moran, that is a Baptized Jew, he believed nothing at all; he had a Concubine called Lucretia to whom he after e≈øpou≈øed his own Son. The Pope that ≈øucceeded him was ≈øo great an Enemy to him, that he cau≈øed all the Windows, Gates, Doors, &c. whereon his Name or Armes were fixed, to be demoli≈øhed or pulled down. When God ≈øpeaketh the word, [Rome be de≈øtroy'd and lye in A≈øhes; Pope come down from your Throne,] the word of God will be obeyed and mu≈øt be immediately brought to pa≈øs: L. Colloqu. 302.
Pride, again ≈øaith Luther, mu≈øt undoubtedly have a Fall, and con≈øequently ≈øo mu≈øt the Pope.

Another of his remarkable prophecies to the ≈øame purpo≈øe is expre≈øt (in Lu. time p. 314.) to this effect. The Pope and his accomplices pre≈øuming on their great power that they ≈øhall never fall, do thereby ha≈øten their fall; and God will overthrow him, and that ≈øuddenly, if our own Securene≈øs, and contempt of Gods word does not hinder it: Let us pray therefore that the ≈øame misfortunes they de≈øign us, may light on their own heads: they have Burned, Hanged, Drowned and Bani≈øhed tho≈øe that were among≈øt us, they will in no wi≈øe be recalled from their Devili≈øh Practi≈øes.

To conclude, we have great hopes the≈øe Prophecies of Luther may accordingly come to pa≈øs, as well as ≈øome others of his prediction have been accompli≈øhed already (though upon other occa≈øions) as plainly appears in his Tom. 2. Epi≈øt. p. 10. & 207. where he foretold the Combu≈øtion which aro≈øe in
Germany: as likewi≈øe the Death of Frederick Elector of Saxony, Tom. 2. Epi≈øt. p. 10. he al≈øo in the ≈øame Book prophe≈øied the Dearth or Famine which happened in Germany according to his prediction. And now I ≈øhall detain you no longer about this Excellent per≈øon, but only pre≈øent you with a ≈ømall Manu≈øcript written by his own hand, and not unproperly called,

div.head: The Generation of Theological Corruption; or a Pedigree of Popi≈øh Principles.
div.p: THE Devil begat Darkne≈øs, Darkne≈øs begat Ignorance, Ignorance begat Errour and his Brethren; Errour begat Freewill and Pre≈øumption, out of Self conceit; Free will begat Merit, Merit begat Forgetfulne≈øs of God, Forgetfulne≈øs of God begat Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion begat Super≈øtition, Super≈øtition begat Satisfaction, Satisfaction begat Oblation of the Ma≈øs, the Oblation of the Ma≈øs begat ∆≤nction, ∆≤nction begat the Prie≈øt, the Prie≈øt begat Mi≈øchief, Mi≈øchief begat Misbelief, Misbelief begat Hypocri≈øie, Hypocri≈øie begat Trading with Offerings for gain, Trading begat Purgatory, Purgatory begat yearly ≈øolemn Vigils, yearly Vigils begat Church-Livings, Church Livings begat Mammon, Mammon begat Superfluity, Superfluity begat Exce≈øs, Exce≈øs begat Rage, Rage begat Licentiou≈øne≈øs, Licentiou≈øne≈øs begat Dominion, Dominion begat Pomp, Pomp begat Ambition, Ambition begat Simony, Simony begat the Pope and his Brethren; the Pope begat the My≈øterie of Iniquity, the My≈øterie of Iniquity begat Sophi≈øtical Divinity, Sophi≈øtical Divinity begat rejecting of the Holy Scriptures, the rejecting of the Holy Scriptures begat Tyranny, Tyranny begat Murdering of Saints, Murdering of Saints begat Abomination, Abomination begat De≈øolation, De≈øolation begat Angui≈øh, Angui≈øh begat Que≈øtioning, Que≈øtioning begat the ≈øearching out the Grounds of Truth; out of which the Pope, called Antichri≈øt, is Revealed. Ex Luthers Prophecies pag. 12.
I Shall now according to my Title, give you a brief account of Mich. No≈øtredamus, and then pre≈øent you with ≈øome of his Prophecies which particularly concern England and France.

He was Born in St. Remy a Town in Provence on the fourteenth of Decemb. 1503. he was bred up in all the Learning in France, and having betaken him≈øelf to the Study of Phy≈øick, grew ≈øo excellent therein, that at la≈øt he became Phy≈øitian to three ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Kings of that Countrey. I ≈øhall give my ≈øelf the le≈øs trouble to demon≈øtrate to the Reader that this learned per≈øon was endowed with the Spirit of Prophecie, becau≈øe I could in≈øtance above a thou≈øand Prophecies of his which have already come to pa≈øs: but before I give you one or two which concerned our Nation as an In≈øtance; I ≈øhall give you the Judgement of one of the greate≈øt wits in our la≈øt age who in brief ≈øayes thus,

God Almighty has cho≈øen out Mich. No≈øtredamus to impart to the world many prodigious and extraordinary things which ≈øhall happen for the Future: again ≈øayes he, next the Apo≈øtles, and Canonical Prophets, No≈øtredamus is to be preferred before any other in the≈øe four things; viz. in the Certainty, the Infallibility, in the Generality and Quantity of his predictions, of which here's an example, written as he did all his other, in old Law French, of which I ≈øhall only give the beginning, and then ≈øet you down the Engli≈øh of them.
Engli≈øhed thus,

q.l: Thirty of London ≈øhall con≈øpire again≈øt their King;
The Plot ≈øhall be made on London-Bridge.

div.p:
What could appear more perfect in number, place and ≈øub≈øtance, to any one that can remember the Plotters again≈øt King Charles the Fir≈øt of ble≈ø≈øed Memory, who≈øe Con≈øpiracy was contrived at the Bear on the Bridge foot: this he foretold almo≈øt a hundred years before it came to pa≈øs: he al≈øo prophe≈øied that a King of England ≈øhould appear on a Scaffold without his Doublet; that he ≈øhould be taken off; and that in
the place where he was to be beheaded, another had been killed three dayes before; all which Circum≈øtances were ≈øadly made true by the Lamented Cata≈øtrophe of that mo≈øt pious Monarch and Martyr.

I ≈øhall now proceed to tho≈øe Prophecies which as yet are unaccompli≈øhed, Pag. 231. 5.‚Äî A quarante huit dei ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , &c. At the Clymacterical year of 8. & 40. at the end of Cancer, ≈øhall be ≈øuch a Drought that the F ‚Ä¢ ≈øh in the Water ≈øhall be boyled to a Con≈øumption; Bearn and Bigorre, by heavenly Fire ≈øhall be in di≈øtre≈øs.
I ≈øhall ≈øay no more but that Bearn and Bigorre, are two Provinces in France; of the re≈øt let the Reader judge.

Another,
Paix ubert√© long temps on ne louera, &c.

Thus Engli≈øhed.
Peace and plenty ≈øhall not long be prai≈øed; before the end of his Reign theFlower de Luce ≈øhall be De≈øerted; bodyes ≈øhall dye by water, Earth ≈øhall be brought, but therein they ≈øhall not be buried.
By Flower de Luce is meant France, expound the re≈øt your ≈øelves. Proph. 82. pag. 141. de No≈øtredamus.
But afterwards he ends his tenth Century, pag. 444. with this Prophecie concerning the future Welfare of England.

q.l: England at la≈øt the Worlds Empire ≈øhall be
And ≈øo ≈øhall remain for Three Hundred and three,
Great Armies ≈øhall pa≈øs both through Land and through Sea
To which the proud Spaniard ≈øhall Strike and give way.
